elements.text: PART ONE
OPENING THEME
SCENE 1. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM.
(FX: A BRITTLE WOODEN BUILDING. VERY, VERY COLD. BEAMS CREAK. A
HANDFUL OF RATS SCURRY ACROSS FLOOR — THEN SCARPER AS A
TRANSMAT HUMS. )
(FX: STEPPING OFF TRANSMAT PAD) We’re here. Fantastic!
(FX: DITTO) It’s brilliant, Dad.
(SOUR) Just wonderful, Roger. See the rats running off?
Please, Veronica. —
Yeah, Mum!
Rats are good. It means life goes on here. Life endures!
Like I said, wonderful. Toasty, turn up the heater in your coat, it’s cold.
Oh, it’s just bracing. And you’re not cold, are you, Toasty?
I’m Toasty!
Fine. Let’s see what’s still working.
FX: THEY WALK. CROSSFADE TO:
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 2
SCENE 2: INT. BUCHMAN KITCHEN. LATER
VERONICA IS EXAMINING THE PLACE. GAS STOVE LIGHTS.
(CALLS) Roger, stove works. So there is some power.
(ENTERING) Told you the Nerva City crew would make sure we'd be okay.
They’re supposed to wait for us. Not have a party and vanish.
Oh, good grief, I didn’t even notice. What a waste.
I can clean up the stuff on the tables, we’ll get one meal out of it. But we’ll have to throw away the rest.
Shame. I haven’t eaten ‘forage porridge’ since — since...
(CUTTING IN) Where’s Toasty?
Looking for a way into the outhouse.
And?
Not likely. The outside entrance is below the ice now, and the tunnel access here is blocked by something.
We need to get in there.
We will. You’ll see. It’s going to be tremendous, Veronica. Restarting our own colony! It’s everything we hoped for.
You hoped for.
F/X: A TRANSMAT HUM IN THE DISTANCE.
Who’s transmatting in now?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 3
(FAR AWAY) OH! OH!
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 4
SCENE 3. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM.
(ONE SECOND AGO, FLIP WAS IN A HOT CITY AND NOW SHE’S HERE AT — 15°C. DURING THE FOLLOWING, HER TEETH WILL START CHATTERING. )
It’s like — like being punched, punched by ice! Urgh-I-feel-sick-I’m-going-to-be-sick!
TOASTY RUNS IN. COMPLETELY FINE WITH THE COLD
Who are you? Are you all right?
Urggggh...
Come off the transmat pad, sit down.
Too cold —
F/X: TRANSMAT HUM. THE DOCTOR ARRIVES.
Oh, quite nippy. That’s a surprise. Ah, there you are, Flip.
Are you okay?
Fine, fine, yes. Probably no more than a 30-degree drop. I’ve been colder, I can tell you.
I meant her. (TO FLIP) Here. Take my coat.
DURING THE FOLLOWING, FLIP RECOVERS RAPIDLY.
(PUTTING ON COAT) Coat, coat, coat — oh. It’s heated! I love this coat. I will never take it off. Have you got two? What about heated trousers?
It’s not that cold, you know.
Minus fifteen Celsius, I should say. Interesting building. I didn’t know there were buildings away from the city.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 5
One second ago I was in Nerva City, where the weather is twenty degrees. He says, “Stand over there, out of the way,” and there turns out to be a transmat to here, the icy ice caves of Iceland.
I think it’s more likely Scotland. Though in this period, that is out of the way.
It is Scotland. You’re on Inchfad Isle on Loch Lomond.
Sure it’s lovely. In the summer.
Come now, Flip. I told you it was a transmat.
You said it was a phone booth.
Nonsense. Anyway, the two are often confused.
I bet they admit it when they are.
You two sound like my Mum and Dad.
Is that a compliment?
Didn’t sound it to me. (TO TOASTY) Sorry, hello. Didn’t mean to drop in like this. Complete accident. Happens to him all the time. You sure you’re okay without your coat?
Oh, yes. Dad says I have hot blood. That’s why he calls me Toasty.
Unusual name.
Yeah, “Doctor”. Hello, Toasty, I’m Flip. Cheers for the coat.
(ENTERING FROM OFF) Which you’ll give back to her right now.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 6
(DITTO) Toasty, step away from them. They’re not the Nerva City Crew.
I’ll have you know we’re not anyone’s crew.
Sounds like a bad Eighties band anyway.
Dad, it’s fine. This is Flip and the Doctor.
Do you know, that sounds like a bad Nineties band?
And you'll find we’re charming company. When you’re not pointing guns at us, that is.
Look, we’re really sorry. Completely didn’t mean to come, I just stood on a transmat without knowing it. And when I can feel my legs again, we’ll be right off. Won’t we, Doctor?
Hmm? Oh, I shouldn’t think so. Far too much to find out. Such as why any of you are here at all. Is this a house?
Doctor, it’s not nice to comment on people’s homes.
It’s alright. Flip, is it? I’m Veronica Buchman and he’s saying no worse than I have.
Hello, Veronica. (TO ROGER) And you are?
Roger Buchman.
My Dad!
That’ll do, Toasty. Go get one of the heaters, see if we can get it working.
They’re by the storage areas.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 7
Call us if they’re too heavy.
EXIT TOASTY.
I take it you’re an engineer, Roger?
First Engineer.
Uniforms haven’t changed much. (TO VERONICA) Which makes you a Technician, hmm?
I was, yes.
(TO DOCTOR) How do you know?
(ASIDE) At this point they’re still using breeding programs, rigid controls over mating, the gene pool. They call it pair bonding.
Means our hearing is first class, for one thing.
Very good.
He means sorry.
He means: can you put the guns away now?
FX: ROGER HAS A RADIO-PHONE WHICH CLICKS ON.
(DISTORT, OVER RADIO) Dad, there’s no power, I can’t see.
(ASIDE) Wow, that’s a proper brick of a phone. What is it, 80s retro?
(ASIDE) Radio-phone. No satellites, not any more. Radiation.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 8
(INTO RADIO) Just inside the door, Toasty. Feel for a metal canister, that’s what we want.
(D) Got it, Dad.
ROGER CLICKS OFF HIS RADIO-PHONE.
Now we’re all friends, could I trouble you for a hot drink? Could you take my friend here to a kitchen?
Yes, of course. Need to warm you up from the inside too.
Go with Veronica, Flip.
You’re really sending me to the kitchen?
What’s usually the warmest room in a house, hmm? Go. If Veronica’s taking you, I’m going to take our engineer Roger for a little walk.
I have more important things to do than talk to you.
You only think so. (WALKS) Come along. —
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 9
SCENE 4. EXT. BUCHMAN HOUSE.
FX: FADE UP. DOOR OPENING INTO ICY-WINDY, FREEZING OUTSIDE.
(STEPPING OUT) Ah, Loch Lomond! Mind you, mid-hundred-and- sixty-second Century, it’s a long time since I was here.
I don’t believe that. Nobody’s been here.
Before you were born, Roger. Or was it after? I can tell you that I don’t remember it being an ice rink.
The loch froze over from top to bottom, fifteen years back. One of the weather changes that made them recall us.
Weather?
You really don’t know anything, do you?
Just travelling through —
Sure. What traveller could be expected to know the year? It’s all right. I know.
You do?

(GOING INTO HIMSELF) It’s sixteen-one-twenty-seven. Barely forty years since we returned to Earth and already we’ve lost so much. Genetic matching used to work, but the population resources are scarce, we’re having to do more with less. A little contamination from the GalSec lot and it all breaks down. The result is people like you.
I very much doubt it.
Not your fault. You need help, I understand. They just shouldn’t pretend you can cope in society. You need your own faculty.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 10
I have all of my faculties, thank you. And one of them tells me it wasn’t weather that drove you back, it was more likely nuclear winds.
Take your pick. It was just stupid to order us back. Colonies were starting to bed in, some were beginning to flourish.
I don’t think you’d have done much flourishing here.
We have to rebuild. We can’t stay in Nerva City, we have to reclaim the Earth and its resources. So we come back here and we start again.
Unless you’re planning to export ice cubes, I don’t see any resources here that you can even get to.
That’s where you’re wrong. The loch’s starting to melt again, we can get that going, reseed it with fish from other colonies.
That loch is a long way from melting. Unless you focus the transmat onto the loch.
Sorry?
Suddenly he’s interested. Let’s go back inside. I’m a lot older than I look and the cold’s even getting to me.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 11
SCENE 5. INT. BUCHMAN KITCHEN.
(ENTERING) Where’s Dad? I’ve got the heater.
Bring it in here by the stove.
Can I help with anything?
There’s a bag of ration packs right behind you. Get me a couple of oh-twos.
Which ones are they?
Orange ones. How do you not know this stuff? Basic survival colour.
I’m new to the whole survival thing.
F/X THE HEATER IS SWITCHED ON.
Oh, I can feel that warming up the place already. Weird how fast you focus on heat when you haven’t got any.
Cold houses are depressing places. Really get to you.
It’s at full now. Shall I get another one?
Not yet. Need to save them. Ask your father where he’s working next.
Okay.
EXIT TOASTY.
Toasty’s twenty next month. She should be enjoying the Olympic
ceremony in Nerva City, not stuck out here with us.
She seems really nice.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 12
Do her good to have some of your attitude.
I don’t follow.
I’m not saying you’re a bad daughter, don’t get me wrong, but you don’t take any of his nonsense. And he clearly respects you for it.
Oh, right. The Doctor’s not my father.
Oh. I see. Well, anyway, it’s late, we must all be hungry. Help me with the porridge.
Porridge! I love porridge. Now that says Scotland to me. (BEAT) Er.. Where is it?
Careful! You’re standing in it, pretty much.
(REALISATION) Eurgh!
It’s just a spill. The crew knocked over what they’d gathered, I think.
Gathered? You don’t gather porridge. (FX: TACKY STRAND OF SLIME IN FINGERS, LIKE SWARFEGA) Yeah, and while we’re about it, it’s not supposed to be sticky and green!
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 13
SCENE 6. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM.
Hard to believe you people can make a transmat pad this slim already.
This part, Doctor, this is just the transmat receiver. The lens pad itself. The transmat engines are in the outhouse.
Which is where the refractors and the diode receptors will be.
Hardly. That’s old technology. I think we’ve moved on a bit Since then.
ENTER TOASTY
Dad —
(TO DOCTOR) No wonder you think you can transmat a loch. Should you really be allowed out?

Think, man. Matter transmitters! The most precision device mankind has ever and will ever make. Built to lock on to the very hadrons and quarks and pinstripes in molecules and transport them away. So you just use the transmat to fasten onto the water molecules in the loch and give them a bit of a shake. Like a microwave oven.
That’s really clever.
Of course it is. I thought of it.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 14
SCENE 7. INT. BUCHMAN KITCHEN. EARLY EVENING
FX: LADLING SLIME INTO SAUCEPANS
‘Forage porridge’, we called it. We found it growing on the forest floor, all those years ago. It’s really very nutritious.
Yeah, proper organic. What is it exactly?
We’re not quite sure. Roger said a fungus. There’s lots that’s missing from the Nerva records. Neither flora nor fauna, you see.
So who was it spilled your porridge? Don’t tell me Goldilocks.
Who’s-? [Goldilocks]
Er.. never mind. The Crew, you said. Something about a Nerva City Crew?

An advance party gets sent out to each new colony — you know, to secure the area, get the hot water running, that sort of thing. They’re supposed to stick around, to help out for the first few days. Not just make a mess and vanish.
F/X THE O2 PACK ON THE HEATER STARTS TO BOIL
Right, water’s ready.
ENTER TOASTY, ROGER AND THE DOCTOR
Ah, Flip, fully recovered?
Yeah. Cheers. Come in, Veronica’s about to dish up her special porridge.
Dad wants to eat now.
Then it’s just as well we’re ready. Roger, we need some more oh-two packs.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 15
We need to conserve them, Veronica.
We won’t always have visitors. And Sheer will bring more.
Sheer?
[VERONICA DISHES UP THE ’PORRIDGE’; WOODEN BOWLS AND CUTLERY ]
He’s joining us after his tour on the space station.
I like Sheer.
(SOUR) Who doesn’t?
Roger, you sit there. (FX: EVERYONE TAKING SEATS) Toasty too. Flip, come by me. And Flip’s.. “friend”.. take a seat.
(SITTING) Thank you. (BEAT) This is porridge-?!?
Forage porridge.
It’s a kind of joke.
I take it you didn’t bring it with you from Nerva City, then?
They find it on the forest floor.
All my life they’ve been going on about it. Forage porridge. (ABOUT TO TUCK IN) It’s supposed to be delicious — (STOPPED BY
DOCTOR) Hey!
I wouldn’t tuck in just yet if I were you, young lady.
Oh! We supposed to say Grace, or something?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 16
I’m afraid this... substance you call ‘forage porridge’, isn’t food.
Nonsense, it’s perfectly good and natural. Eat up, Toasty.
I’m serious. This isn’t food. It’s mucus.
Mucus.
If I’m not mistaken, and I so rarely am these days, it’s Wirrn mucus.
What’s Wirrn?
Yeah, he said mucus?
Doctor, you’re worrying Toasty.
It’s not very polite, transmatting in and trying to frighten us.
What’s Wirrn?
Again, he said mucus. —
They haven’t been seen in decades. They were like giant insects, I suppose —
Adult Wirrn are like insects, yes. But they start out as pupae, and as pupae, they leave slime trails.
(FX: PUSHING BOWL AWAY) Mucus.
This is fresh. You said there should have been a party here before you?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 17
A Nerva City Crew. Just a pair of multi-skills.
Trail. Slime trail. You said the crew must have spilled that stuff, but when we got here, there was like a massive streak of it, all along the floor?
Show me where it led.
Well — all under the table, all the way to the pantry door.
(WALKING OVER) This pantry door?
Uh, yeah. —
And you didn’t open it?
No.
Leave that alone. I don’t know about any ‘pantry’, there’s a junction box in there.
(TOUCHING DOOR) Warm. Toasty, in fact. The first place they’d
go.
(NERVOUS) Doctor, don’t —
It’s quite all right, I know what I’m doing. —
FX: DOCTOR OPENS DOOR — AND TWO HUGE HUSKS FALL OUT.
TOASTY/FLIP:
BOTH SCREAM
Oh, my God.
Toasty, don’t look.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 18
What are they?
What’s left of two multi-skills, I presume. Husks. Abandoned once they’d been eaten.
Those were really people?
That’s it. Everybody, we’re leaving.
You've been looking for an excuse, Veronica, and —
And now I’ve found one, yes!
Anything to split the family up. We’re staying.
I strongly recommend you leave.
Wouldn’t catch me staying where something does that to people.
Roger. Focus on this. I came here to keep the family together. But it’s just a little hard to keep us together if we’re going to die.
You too, Flip. You’re going back to the TARDIS.
Oh, it’s fine, not getting rid of me.
[LIKES IT] You’re very cheeky to your Dad!
He’s not my Dad!
Transmat, right now. Including you, Roger. And you, Doctor.
FX: ALL EXIT. CROSSFADE TO:
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 19
SCENE 8. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM. AFTERNOON
FX: ALL ENTER
Everybody onto the pad.
Come on Toasty, stand with me.
All these years working to get back and we’re just running away.
Hmm. Rather crude timer on this transmat.
I designed that.
Never mind, I’m sure you did your best. Everybody on? And ...
F/X COUNTDOWN BLEEPS
. here we go.
HE RUNS FOR THE TRANSMAT
Bunch up then, give me some room.
F/X COUNTDOWN BLEEPS INTENSIFY, THEY’RE ALMOST DONE
Goodbye Loch Lomond.
(F/X COUNTDOWN CLIMAXES — - AND NOTHING HAPPENS. BEAT. )
Thought you were the great transmat expert, Doctor.
Boys! Just get it fixed.
Let’s think. We know the power’s working.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 20
And the co-ordinates are a straight reverse to Nerva City, the fault can’t be there.
F/X WARNING BLEEP
Something’s coming through. Everybody, off the pad.
THEY GET OFF
Roger, quickly. Transmats used to need pads or spheres at both ends: is that still true?
No, not for years. I designed pad-to-site systems a decade ago.
Why?
Hopefully academic interest. Here we go.
F/X TRANSMAT HUM STARTS...
It could be Sheer, coming early from the space station.
I hope he’s wearing a warm spacesuit, then.
(CONFIDENTIALLY) I like him in those, too.
I get it. Not so much warm as hot, right?
(F/X THE TRANSMAT HUM COMPLETES. BEAT)
So, not Sheer, then.
What is it?
It’s a video beacon.
(F/X A LISTEN-UP CHIME. THE BEACON PLAYS A RECORDED MESSAGE FROM PAUL, A BUREAUCRAT. )
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 21
(RECORDED) Hear me, citizens of Nerva City.
It’s Paul.
(RECORDED) Pioneers of Nerva City and our new Earth.
[TO FLIP] Head of the colony program.

(RECORDED) As Nerva City strains to provide shelter and food to our population, it is to you we look for the future of mankind. Each of you, in your new homes, your new colonies, what you do every day secures a brighter future for us all. For your benefit, Nerva City Colony Board has reluctantly made transmats one-way only. Know that it was a difficult but a necessary decision. And when this message ends, extra supplies will be beamed to your pad. I thank you for the sacrifices I know you will continue to make on our behalf.
F/X TRANSMAT HUMS.
Not the best news I’ve ever had.
I was on the board! How can they do this?
To get rid of you.
Mum!
That’s quite a lot of supplies they’ve beamed in. Not to sound violent, but is there any chance they included more guns?
Doesn’t matter. Wirrn survive just about anything you can think of. The vacuum of space. Everything but electricity.
Lovely.
Veronica, Roger. Can you call this Nerva Board?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 22
No.
We've only got our radio-phones.
Short-range comms.
Wait, how were the Nerva City Crew supposed to move on to their next job?
Encoded pass IDs, probably.
So why don’t we find those?
Though there was nothing like that by the husks.
Because it’s a molecular-level code, Doctor. The transmat would analyze their DNA and let them through. We’1ll have to rewire the transmat engines.
They’re in the outhouse.
And it’s impossible to get in there.
Not impossible.
But not practical, I see. Any other colonies? Anything in range of your radio-phones?
We’re the northernmost colony.
There’1l be a transmat substation over at Aldochlay. It was going to be to the router for Europe. It’s got to be less than four kilometres away.
The island’s got a boat channel, maybe there’s still something seaworthy.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 23
Nothing could sail that loch.
Then either we find a way into the outhouse or we walk over the ice to Aldochlay. Normally I’d enjoy a good stretch of the legs, but —
But until we know where the Wirrn is, we could be walking into trouble.
Two Wirrn? Maybe three if it was a big crew.
The eggs didn’t come from thin air. We have to assume there’s a swarm. And if it’s not in your house, there aren’t many places it can be.
BEAT
We'd just need one person to get across the loch and work the
transmat for the rest of us, wouldn’t we?
So now you’re willing to split up.
I’m thinking of the microlite.
Oh.
BEAT
You mean my brother’s microlite.
LONG, LONG BEAT. ROGER AND VERONICA DON’T KNOW WHAT TO SAY.
Before he died.
How long have you known?
Since military recruiters came to school. They said soldiers have regular visits home.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 24
I’m sorry, Toasty, —
And I heard you arguing about him.
Brothers are always trouble.
(TO FLIP) So are parents. (TO ROGER AND VERONICA) It’s okay. I’ve had years to get used to it. Found his diary in storage too. So I know about the microlite and that he loved to fly.
He did. He used to fly over the loch.
So shall we get it?
CROSSFADE TO:
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 25
SCENE 9. INT. BUCHMAN HOUSE. SUPPLY ROOM EVENING
There’s still no light in here.
I found a torch in the kitchen.
(F/X SHE SWITCHES IT ON — - AND WITH A SQUEAL, RATS RUN AWAY)
So where’s this microlite?
It’s back here.
And where’s the rest of it?
It is smaller than I remember.
Can I fly it?
No. Too dangerous.
We might not have a choice. That frame won’t support anyone else. And that’s if the engine still works.
F/X THE ENGINE WORKS. ROGER HAS STARTED IT AND IS TRIUMPHANT.
You were saying, Doctor?
F/X THE ENGINE DIES IMMEDIATELY.
Yes, I was.
How far did you say it is?
[DEMONSTRATING] It’s fine. You just start it here, wait for it to catch, then pull out the choke. Not too long. Pop it back in, engine’s fine.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 26
You’re sure?
Totally. Might get the odd flutter but just give it choke for another second and you’1ll be fine.
Okay, I will.
You will what?
Come on, Doctor. I’m the lightest one here... not boasting or anything.
I’m lighter.
(TO TOASTY) You stay right where you are.
See? It’s me or it’s nobody. I mean... how hard can it be? So, which way’s Aldochlay?
CROSSFADE TO:
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 27
SCENE 10. EXT. BUCHMAN HOUSE. EVENING
(EVERYBODY OUT, CARRYING THE MICROLITE. IT’S EVEN WINDIER. THE MICROLITE’S FABRIC FLAPS, THE ENGINE IS HEAVY AND THE METAL FRAME SCRAPES AGAINST THE DOOR)
Watch the door.
I’m glad to say, the metal frame looks more solid than I thought.
And the engine’s heavy enough.
Flip, you don’t have to—
Do this? I think we both know I do. And besides, Roger’s given me a crash course... er.
Yes, not a happy choice of words.
And anyway, this is kind of why I came with you, Doctor. To do exciting things. No point just sitting around freezing when—
You can be up there freezing. Flip, I can’t make up my mind on whether you’re one of the bravest girls I’ve met... or simply foolhardy.
I’ll keep you guessing, then, shall I?
Here we go.
Flip, are you sure?
This isn’t exactly ideal flying weather, is it now?
You want to wait?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 28
No. No, I see your point. If the Wirrn aren’t in the house, they’re presumably out here somewhere. Pupae can move quite fast, but it’s a big loch.
So let’s go. How will I recognise the substation?
Once you clear Inchfad, you fly over Inchconnachan Isle and then Aldochlay is the next land. There’s just one building on the coast.
So I can’t miss it. And I can land there?
There was a strip near it. Remember what I said... take her down nice and steady and then throttle back.
Right’.
We’1ll talk you through the transmat controls when you get there.
MORE FABRIC FLAPPING: A LITTLE TEARING TOO
Good, one less thing to worry about. Can we fasten the wing fabric with anything? That’s one more thing to worry about.
I’d like to go, Flip.
I know, Toasty. Call it a thanks for your coat.
Speaking of which...
Yes, I guessed that. Too heavy. Okay.
SHE TAKES OFF HER COAT AND HANDS IT TO THE DOCTOR
Remind me of this next time we’re anywhere warm. Here you go.
I’m going to want that right back, though.
F/X ROGER STARTS THE MICROLITE ENGINE
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 29
We’re ready.
Thank you, Flip.
Be careful now.
(SITTING INTO THE MICROLITE) I will, don’t you — oooooh, aah, the metal’s freezing already. Just four kilometres, you promise?
Take a radio-phone.
Hey, that’s mine, I —
That’s the thing to worry about, Roger, your phone.
I used to be the same. Always upgrading. Any chance this has got a GPS app on it?
Flip. See that gap in the clouds? Once you’re airborne, turn right around and aim for that. And try to get there while there’s any light left.
F/X THE ENGINE SPLUTTERS
I know. Choke.
F/X THE ENGINE RETURNS TO NORMAL. FLIP GUNS IT A BIT.
You’d better all stand clear.
Good luck.
Keep your radio on, okay?
(QUIETLY) Flip? I’m still not sure you understand how dangerous this 2S.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 30
I’ve already died once, what can be worse? Now, if I don’t get
going, I’ll be shivering too much to steer straight.
Flip, if I could fly this —
I'll be careful.
Remember, if you can’t see the strip or it’s blocked in any
way, land on the loch: it’s smooth, uninterrupted ice.
Okay, Doctor. Aldochlay or bust.
(F/X ONE MORE GUN OF THE ENGINE AND SHE’S OFF: DURING THE FOLLOWING SHE’LL RATTLE ACROSS THE ICY ISLAND AND THEN UP THE AIR.)
(TO HIMSELF) Remarkable girl.
I’ll go get the transmat ready.
ROGER EXITS

DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 3

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 3. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM.
DOCTOR WHO: (ONE SECOND AGO, FLIP WAS IN A HOT CITY AND NOW SHE’S HERE AT — 15°C. DURING THE FOLLOWING, HER TEETH WILL START CHATTERING. )
FLIP: It’s like — like being punched, punched by ice! Urgh-I-feel-sick-I’m-going-to-be-sick!
TOASTY: Who are you? Are you all right?

TOASTY: I meant her. (TO FLIP) Here. Take my coat.
FLIP: (PUTTING ON COAT) Coat, coat, coat — oh. It’s heated! I love this coat. I will never take it off. Have you got two? What about heated trousers?

DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 5
FLIP: One second ago I was in Nerva City, where the weather is twenty degrees. He says, “Stand over there, out of the way,” and there turns out to be a transmat to here, the icy ice caves of Iceland.
DOCTOR: I think it’s more likely Scotland. Though in this period, that is out of the way.
TOASTY: It is Scotland. You’re on Inchfad Isle on Loch Lomond.

DOCTOR: Unusual name.

ROGER: (ENTERING FROM OFF) Which you’ll give back to her right now.

VERONICA: (DITTO) Toasty, step away from them. They’re not the Nerva City Crew.

TOASTY: (DISTORT, OVER RADIO) Dad, there’s no power, I can’t see.

ROGER: (INTO RADIO) Just inside the door, Toasty. Feel for a metal canister, that’s what we want.

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 4. EXT. BUCHMAN HOUSE.
DOCTOR: (STEPPING OUT) Ah, Loch Lomond! Mind you, mid-hundred-and- sixty-second Century, it’s a long time since I was here.

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 8. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM. AFTERNOON
VERONICA: Everybody onto the pad.

ROGER: And the co-ordinates are a straight reverse to Nerva City, the fault can’t be there.

DOCTOR: Roger, quickly. Transmats used to need pads or spheres at both ends: is that still true?

PAUL: (RECORDED) Hear me, citizens of Nerva City.

PAUL: (RECORDED) Pioneers of Nerva City and our new Earth.
VERONICA: [TO FLIP] Head of the colony program.
PAUL: (RECORDED) As Nerva City strains to provide shelter and food to our population, it is to you we look for the future of mankind. Each of you, in your new homes, your new colonies, what you do every day secures a brighter future for us all. For your benefit, Nerva City Colony Board has reluctantly made transmats one-way only. Know that it was a difficult but a necessary decision. And when this message ends, extra supplies will be beamed to your pad. I thank you for the sacrifices I know you will continue to make on our behalf.

DOCTOR: Doesn’t matter. Wirrn survive just about anything you can think of. The vacuum of space. Everything but electricity.
FLIP: Lovely.
DOCTOR: Veronica, Roger. Can you call this Nerva Board?
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 22
ROGER: No.
VERONICA: We've only got our radio-phones.
ROGER: Short-range comms.
FLIP: Wait, how were the Nerva City Crew supposed to move on to their next job?
DOCTOR: Encoded pass IDs, probably.
FLIP: So why don’t we find those?
DOCTOR: Though there was nothing like that by the husks.
ROGER: Because it’s a molecular-level code, Doctor. The transmat would analyze their DNA and let them through. We’1ll have to rewire the transmat engines.
TOASTY: They’re in the outhouse.
VERONICA: And it’s impossible to get in there.
ROGER: Not impossible.
DOCTOR: But not practical, I see. Any other colonies? Anything in range of your radio-phones?
ROGER: We’re the northernmost colony.
VERONICA: There’1l be a transmat substation over at Aldochlay. It was going to be to the router for Europe. It’s got to be less than four kilometres away.
ROGER: The island’s got a boat channel, maybe there’s still something seaworthy.

DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 112
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 92. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING
FLIP: You agreed!
DARE: I still do. But I’ve switched off all transmats, I’ve the authority to do that. What I don’t have is the power to switch one back on. Nobody can transmat to Loch Lomond.
PAUL: Dare, stand away from this intruder.
FLIP: Me?
SHEER: Flip, Dare, I’ve explained —
PAUL: And I’ve heard enough. Dare, how can you believe this nonsense?
DARE: I started with the evidence and worked backwards. Sir.
FLIP: You’re Paul, aren’t you?
PAUL: And you’re well briefed for someone who says she’s just transmatted in.
DARE: Sir, let’s just sort this out.
SHEER: We’ll all transmat over to Loch Lomond.
FLIP: Great.
PAUL: No.
FLIP: Why not? They need help!
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 113
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 93. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
ROGER: The transmat was supposed to copy out Toasty’s DNA.
DOCTOR: Transmats don’t copy DNA, they move it from one place to another.
ROGER: This one does. I spent years working it out. Wrote the software to turn this pad into what I needed.
DOCTOR: Humans. Not so much indomitable as exasperating.
ROGER: I’m sorry?
DOCTOR: You may have written your local software superbly — I suppose that’s possible — but this pad runs on a network of transmats. Your system beamed out Toasty’s DNA but the network lock told it to not transmat it anywhere, including back into her. So it should have stayed in the system.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 114
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 94. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
PAUL: What do you want, girl? Are you trying to stop the Olympic?
FLIP: I’m talking about Wirrn, you’re talking about sport?!
DARE: What has sport got to do with the Olympic?
SHEER: I’m with Flip, we have to focus on the Wirrn.
PAUL: There are no Wirrn.
SHEER: Then let one of us prove it. One way or the other. What would it cost us?
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 115
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 95. EXT. LOCH LOMOND BUCHMAN HOUSE. MORNING.
DOCTOR WHO: (F/X WIRRN EVERYWHERE: VERONICA SWINGS THE CABLE AND IT CONNECTS WITH ELECTRIC SHOCKS. )
VERONICA: (INTO RADIO) Doctor! We’re surrounded!
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 116
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 96. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
DOCTOR: (INTO RADIO) Just a minute, Veronica.
ROGER: The transmat buffer is huge, it’s built to hold the images of as many people as can stand on the pad.
DOCTOR: And it’s swamped with data, I can’t tell what’s Toasty.
ROGER: I can. She’s my daughter. Copy my DNA out and you’1l be
ROGER: match.
DOCTOR: You’d be lost the same way.
ROGER: Not now I know about the network precedence.
ROGER: pad, you run my routine and control it.
DOCTOR: I’m beginning to change my mind about you, Roger.
ROGER: Do you think I’d let you do this if I still thought you
ROGER: idiot?
DOCTOR: Get on the pad.
DOCTOR: I’m on it...
DOCTOR: Got it... Matching DNA...
ROGER: Toasty went through that.
DOCTOR: Apparently not.
DOCTOR: I put Toasty through that.
DOCTOR: able to
DOCTOR: I’'1l stand on the
DOCTOR: were an
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 117
ROGER: What?
DOCTOR: Your DNA doesn’t match anything still in the buffer. Wait here.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 118
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 97: NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING
DARE: Sheer, stand on the pad.
FLIP: And prepare yourself, it’s incredibly cold by the loch.
SHEER: Unnerstan.
PAUL: Just get on with it.
DARE: Transmat network coming back online... Just a moment while it restarts...
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 119
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 98. EXT. LOCH LOMOND BUCHMAN HOUSE. MORNING.
VERONICA: Doctor! I can’t hold them!
DOCTOR: (CALLING FROM OFF) Then leave it! Please, Veronica! Come back inside!
DOCTOR: (ONE MORE FRITZING SHOCK OF THE CABLE AND VERONICA MAKES IT TO THE DOOR WITH THE DOCTOR. )
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 120
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 99: INT. BUCHMAN HOUSE
DOCTOR WHO: (DOCTOR AND VERONICA TUMBLE IN, PULLING THE DOOR BEHIND THEM. THEY’RE INSIDE BUT NOT IN THE TRANSMAT ROOM YET. )
DOCTOR: Help me find a way to block the door.
DOCTOR: Careful, you’1ll have someone’s eye out with that!
VERONICA: Never mind that. Where’s the nearest power junction?
DOCTOR: Power junction? Why?
VERONICA: If only we could get out to run cables right into the loch, we [could —]
DOCTOR: Veronica. There’s something you have to tell me.
VERONICA: No time to talk, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Please, Veronica. I can’t get Toasty back if you don’t tell me. Veronica, who is Toasty’s father?
VERONICA: You’re quicker than Roger is. Sheer. Sheer Jawn is Toasty’s Dad.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 121
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 100: NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING
SHEER: Flip, I’1l1 tell the Doctor you’re here.
FLIP: Thanks.
PAUL: Sheer, do no such thing. It’s probably a signal.
FLIP: Oh, I give up.
SHEER: Don’t worry, Flip. I’1l1l know the lockout codes, I’1l be beaming back with everybody soon.
DARE: Almost there. Whole system was shut down, it’s taking — here, here we go. Power’s back on, systems are live.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 122
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 101. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
ROGER: (INTO RADIO) Iron, I’ve matched my DNA to yours. Transmatting now.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 123
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 102. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING
DARE: Loch Lomond coordinates set. Transmatting now.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 124
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 103: BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM
ROGER: Locked. Getting a connection.
DOCTOR: Roger! No!
VERONICA: What are you doing? Have you found Toasty?
ROGER: I’ve found Iron! I’m transmatting him right out of the Wirrn.
ROGER: What’s — ? There are two signals.
DOCTOR: You've not restored network precedence, someone else is beaming in. Someone from Nerva City. Override it! There’s nothing to tell the pad it’s getting two bodies instead of one signal.
VERONICA: Oh, my God. Sheer!
DOCTOR: His DNA’s blending, I can’t save him.
SHEER: Veronica!
SHEER: (SHEER SCREAMS — TRANSMAT HUM ENDS — AND IRON/WIRRN CHIRRUPS — AND SHEER DIES. SHEER IS NOW ABSORBED. )
SHEER: IRON/WIRRN: Mum!
VERONICA: My — my boy?
DOCTOR: Keep back, both of you. That’s an adult Wirrn.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 125
ROGER: Iron? Are you in there, son?
ROGER: IRON/WIRRN: Don’t you recognise me, Dad?
ROGER: Why couldn’t I beam him out of you?
DOCTOR: Iron is long gone, Roger.
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN-SHEER/WIRRN: Oh, I understand now. Mum and Sheer. (IN sorry, Veronica.
DOCTOR: That is fascinating: he’s absorbed Sheer’
DOCTOR: experience through transmaterialization. beamed out and been eaten.
ROGER: Veronica? You and Sheer?
VERONICA: SHEER’S VOICE) I’m
VERONICA: s knowledge and I had assumed Iron had
VERONICA: Don’t expect an apology. Sheer, Iron, are you really both in —
VERONICA: in this thing? Can we get you out?
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 126
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 104: NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING
PAUL: Now, I’ve reopened all the transmats and they will stay that
PAUL: way, do you hear?
DARE: Sir.
PAUL: Then sir is going back to the Olympic. Let me know when Sheer returns.
FLIP: Dare...
DARE: I’m thinking the same thing. He shouldn’t have reopened the transmat network.
FLIP: Send me to Loch Lomond.
DARE: Do you ever just ask politely for what you want?
FLIP: Do you know, that never seems to work for me.
DARE: Try it some time. It’ll make a difference. Transmatting now.
FLIP: Loch Lomond, here I come.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 127
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 105: INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT ROOM
DOCTOR WHO: IRON/WIRRN: You’re not transmatting me out to the loch, not again, Dad.
ROGER: It’s not me — I haven’t touched anything.
ROGER: (FX A MANDIBLE CUTTING THE AIR — - AND HITTING THE TRANSMAT CONTROLS )
DOCTOR: Watch out! Roger, run.
VERONICA: Where to? Where can we possibly go now?
ROGER: Iron! I brought you here! I’1l never send you away again. This is someone else beaming in. Get off the pad.
ROGER: IRON/WIRRN:
ROGER: Sheer understands transmats. I don’t need you after all, father.
VERONICA: ROGER!
DOCTOR: (GRIM) Leave him, Veronica. He’s dead. Nothing we can do.
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN: Stopping the transmat cycle.
DOCTOR: Why? Is it getting too crowded in there?
VERONICA: Take me too. Can you transmat me inside it? We’d all be together.
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 128
DOCTOR: I don’t think so.
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN: What a clumsy timer design on the transmat.
DOCTOR: What are you doing?
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN: Undoing the lockouts. Now I know everything I need to know. I’m going to beam myself to Nerva City, Doctor.
DOCTOR: You don’t want to stay here and talk about it? I can help you.
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN: My eggs must be laid soon. And there is no better place than Nerva City.
DOCTOR: One Wirrn against a city? You’d be better off here, with the rest of the swarm.
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN:
DOCTOR: The swarm is only waiting for me to transmat out. I’m beaming myself to every transmat pad across the city, every pad in every colony. Simultaneously. I step ontothis lens pad anda thousand copies of me step off pads all across the world.
DOCTOR: I won’t allow it.
DOCTOR: IRON/WIRRN: It’s already done. Transmatting now.
DOCTOR: CRASH IN CLOSING THEME.
DOCTOR: END OF EPISODE
DOCTOR WHO: THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 129

elements.text: PART FOUR
OPENING THEME
IRON/WIRRN:
The swarm is only waiting for me to transmat out. I’m beaming myself to every transmat pad across the city, every pad in every colony. Simultaneously. I step onto this lens pad and a
thousand copies of me step off pads all across the world.
I won’t allow it.
IRON/WIRRN: It’s already done. Transmatting now.
F/X TRANSMAT HUM
SCENE 107. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
What happened?
The transmat cycle was rejected at Loch Lomond.
Why would Sheer stop me from coming?
SHE STEPS OFF THE PAD
Wirrn. There must be Wirrn, and I sent him there.
Not necessarily. Could be [anything. ]
(F/X TRANSMAT HUM — AND THE SCUTTLING, CHIRRUPING WIRRN APPEARS. )
Oh my — Wirrn!!!
F/X SOOTHING ALARMS START
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 130
ALARM 1: Intruder in transmat bay 7. Response teams will soon report to bay 7.
He followed me. That’s Iron.
(INTO RADIO) Emergency: security to bay 7. Authorisation Dare Nine Seven Three.
ALARM 1: Intruder in transmat bay 7. Response teams will soon report to bay 7.
IRON/WIRRN: Yes. Bring bodies. We need so many bodies.
ALARM 1: Intruder in transmat bay 7. Response teams will soon report to bay 7.
Dare, which button — (INTO RADIO) Emergency, emergency: evacuate the building.
(INTO RADIO) Authorisation Dare Nine-Seven-Three. (TO FLIP) And that means us too.
IRON/WIRRN: Don’t go, Flip.
It knows you?
IRON/WIRRN-SHEER/WIRRN: (IN SHEER’S VOICE) Ag man. Don’t you know me, my Dare?
Sheer? Oh no, no, no —
Dare! Come on, we’ve got to get out.
THEY EXIT
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 131
SCENE 108. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
I can’t believe Iron’s gone again.
Well, don’t worry, he’ll be back soon enough.
How do you mean?
What I mean is, Iron — (CATCHES SELF) — the Swarm Leader has transmatted copies of himself to every pad on the planet. And this is a pad.
He’s going to beam here? Where is he, then?
Latency. Takes time for the signal to reach each pad on the network. I only hope he didn’t think of that.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 132
SCENE 109. EXT. NERVA CITY. NIGHT (CROWDS RUNNING, SCREAMING. TRANSMATS HUMMING. AND THAT CHIRRUPING IS GROWING. )
They’re — just —
Everywhere. How?
I don’t know. Dare, please, concentrate: where can we go where there are no pads?
Nowhere. The pads are everywhere. Just everywhere.
CHIRRUPPING BECOMES A ROAR, A FEEDING FRENZY.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 133
SCENE 110. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
TRANSMAT HUMS: AN IRON/WIRRN BEAMS IN
Here we go. Wirrn business.
IRON/WIRRN: What’s gone wrong? Mum? Doctor?
Oh, my poor boy.
So much for your grand plan, eh, Iron? Didn’t go very far, did you?
IRON/WIRRN-SHEER/WIRRN: (SOUNDING MORE LIKE SHEER) Power did not fluctuate. (SOUNDING LIKE IRON) Dad would’ve known.
Sorry to interrupt your debate, but I know what you’re
forgetting.
IRON/WIRRN: What?
Me.
F/X PRESSING TRANSMAT BUTTONS
NO!
IRON/WIRRN: NO!
TRANSMAT HUM
How — what have you done to him?
He — with Sheer’s knowledge — had taken out the transmat locks. So I could beam him away.
You've ‘transmatted my son out into Loch Lomond. Haven’t you?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 134
I didn’t have time to enter new coordinates, just selected a recent location. He’1ll be back soon enough...!
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 135
SCENE 111. EXT. NERVA CITY. NIGHT
WIRRN SLICING AND CHOMPING AS THE CROWD SCREAMS
We're finished. Nerva City is finished. Mankind is finished!
Must be something we can do.
We can send emergency beacons. Warn the colonies.
If the Wirrn haven’t already reached them.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 136
SCENE 112. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
MORE CREAKING WOOD, WOODEN WALLS BREAKING IN THE HOUSE.
With or without Iron, they’re breaking in.
Let them come.
I’d never imagined you giving up hope, Veronica.
I’d never imagined my family dying, Doctor.
Then think of all the families in Nerva City.
F/X TRANSMAT BLEEPS
I’ll spit if I hear another transmat.
No, no, that’s — Veronica, that’s the backup completed. I can take anything I like from it.
Forget it, Doctor. You’ve spent all this time telling me to accept that Iron is gone but I get it, I understand I’ve lost Toasty.
Stand on the pad. It didn’t work with Roger because he’s not her father, but you will share enough DNA with her to match.
I won’t be able to bear it if you’re wrong again.
Me? Wrong? Stand right in the centre, please. And here we go.
F/X TRANSMAT HUM
LONG BEAT
Nothing. Again.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 137
I never need the TARDIS to know where we are in Earth history: I just measure how little patience the humans have got. I have your DNA in the system, all I need now is to...
F/X MORE WOOD CREAKING, SHATTERING
They’re in the building.
Yes, yes, they would be.
I’m going to reopen the passage to the outhouse. If the transmat’s just going to drop us into Wirrn City, the outhouse passage is our only bet.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 138
SCENE 103. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
(IT’S QUIET INSIDE BUT THERE’S THE DISTANT SOUND OF CROWDS AND DYING OUTSIDE THE BUILDING. )
Building’s empty. Everybody’s evacuated.
Quiet. We’re near the main security area. If Wirrn really have Sheer’s knowledge, they’1ll have gone there. I’1ll peek ahead.
I’ll keep an eye out behind us.
DARE EDGES FORWARD: LONG BEAT
Oh — oh, my lights, are they bodies? All of them?
FLIP JOINS HER
They’re turning the council building into a nursery. Some of that... stuff... looks like eggs inside the bodies.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 139
SCENE 104. INT. BUCHMAN TRANSMAT. MORNING.
CRASH OF WOOD: THE WIRRN ARE THROUGH THE HOUSE.
Veronica! Hold them off, I’m nearly done — Veronica!
A WIRRN HAS ENTERED THE ROOM. CHIRRUP
Oh, do stop sounding so happy about it.
(THIS WIRRN IS ONE FROM THE LOCH: SO IT’S A NEW VOICE, NOT IRON, SHEER OR ROGER)
So hungry, so long.
F/X BUTTONS AND SWITCHES
I prefer “so long”, if you’re offering a choice.
F/X TRANSMAT HUM STARTING
I’m the Doctor, by the way. Don’t get up.
CHIRRUP — THE WIRRN ADVANCING — AND LUNGING
No, no, no, you don’t.
CHIRRUP
Now, here we are, you see? If you watch instead of eating everybody, you learn so much more. I’ve got a match on Toasty’s DNA. Transmatting now.
F/X TRANSMAT HUM
Doctor?
Hello, Toasty — run!
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 140
SCENE 105. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
VIDEO BEACON BLEEPS: DARE IS ABOUT TO RECORD A MESSAGE.
Recording. Hear me, everybody. Colonies, switch off your transmats now. Never start them again. We are about to lose Nerva City to the Wirrn. Save yourselves.
(INTO RECORDING) Look. This is an outside view from the council building now.
F/X ROARING/CHIRRUPING WIRRN AND PEOPLE SCREAMING
Sorry. But this is real.
Good luck to us all. Sending.
F/X TRANSMAT HUM
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 141
SCENE 106. INT. BUCHMAN OUTHOUSE. MORNING.
(THE ODD FRITZ OF ELECTRICAL CABLE: VERONICA IS PULLING WIRES FROM THE TRANSMAT ENGINE. )
Doctor, that thing is right behind us and — Mum?
VERONICA HUGS TOASTY
What’s going on? What are you doing?
Toasty? Oh, my sweet, sweet child.
Get off! What’s the matter with everybody?
Let her hug you, Toasty. You don’t know what she’s been through. And I’m very sorry to say you will.
DISTANT CHIRRUP AND THUMP, THUMP
Help me barricade the door.
But Dad’s out there.
I’m sorry, Toasty, he isn’t.
He was right there!
He transmatted you off the pad hours ago. I’m afraid while you’ve —
THUMP
- really, got to brace the door. Toasty, while you were away —
This is my job, Doctor. I’m her mother. You were beamed away by accident, Toasty.
Like Iron? Dad did that to me?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 142
FX: TRANSMAT ENGINES START TO HUM.
Your father was killed trying to save you.
Something’s transmatting in.
We've got to stop the cycle, they’1ll appear right in front of the Wirrn.
(FX: DURING THE FOLLOWING, THE DOCTOR AND VERONICA OPEN ENGINE PANELS )
Look for access panels. There are no controls here, but we should be able to find the lines to short out the transmat.
Could it be Dad?
NOBODY ANSWERS. LONG BEAT — AND THEN THE HUM STOPS.
How did you do that, Doctor? I got to the power cables but no control lines.
The panels say the control lines rerouted, avoiding any damage I could do. But still the cycle stopped itself before anyone beamed in.
What happened to the people transmatting in?
I suppose it’s a failsafe: keep the control lines working to finish the cycle but assume there’s a problem and cancel the transport.
Doctor?
It wasn’t your father, Toasty. But no, they didn’t die. If it was even a person trying to get here.
What else could it be?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 143
Supplies? Nerva City tried to beam us more ration packs? What good is that?
I’1ll tell you what I’d do. I’d have transmatted over a bomb.
Taking out the house doesn’t affect any Wirrn in the city, now, does it?
There are hundreds of Wirrn on the loch. Any way you can kill Wirrn in their own swarm has to be a good idea. Even if not for US's
Well, if that was the plan, we’ve prevented that for now. We’re going to need the transmat, though. Veronica, check you’ve got the power cables attached. I’m going to rewire the control lines again.
Transmat as a weapon. It’s got possibilities.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 144
SCENE 107. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
Logs say the beacon got to all colonies...
Including —
. except Loch Lomond. I’m sorry, Flip.
FLIP SINKS.
I don’t know what to do now. What about the rest of the colonies, how will we find out if they heard us?
If the colonies start switching off their transmats, the network grid will shrink to just Nerva City. There’s no other way to tell.
ENTER AN IRON/WIRRN
IRON/WIRRN-SHEER/WIRRN: You could just ask me.
Iron!
IRON/WIRRN-SHEER/WIRRN:
Iron and Sheer and more. One of whom knows that you’re reaching for the security hold, Dare. If you’re lucky, if there’s still a fission gun in there, it can’t harm me.
My Sheer was better at keeping secrets. What do you want?
IRON/WIRRN-SHEER/WIRRN: What we need. What we’ve got. Wherever there’s a transmat, there is Iron. I am everywhere on the face of this planet.
So let’s transmat you off the planet.
TRANSMAT HUM — IRON/WIRRN IS GONE.
Where’ve you sent him?
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 145
Ported him into the sky. Right now he’s falling back to Earth,
burning up in the atmosphere.
The Doctor wouldn’t approve — but thanks.
One down, just a city full of Wirrn to go.
And no Doctor.
FX: FISSION GUN CHARGING
Still, look on the bright side. That insect was
fission gun.
right about the
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 146
SCENE 108. INT. BUCHMAN OUTHOUSE. MORNING.
Veronica? Control lines say there’s no power — because you’ve disconnected the power coupling cables.
You said it, Doctor. We can use a weapon. I pulled power cables from the transmat engines and while you had your head in the panel controls, I connected the ends to the ice.
I don’t understand what you’ve done. I don’t understand anything.
Toasty, there are now power cables running into the loch. The next time we or anyone uses that transmat, anyone, anything in the water will be electrocuted and killed.
Hasn’t there been enough killing?
Yes. By Wirrn.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 147
SCENE 109. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
Funny how quiet it is in here.
Must be the only place that is. Two A.M. I should be singing in the Noah Centre. Wonder if anyone’s still alive out there. Wonder if Paul made it to his dinner.
Do you have any family, Dare?
Just my guitar and — and I was going to say Sheer.
Sorry. Hard to grasp all the killing. Killing was always something in films and you knew it’d be all right in the end.
Don’t see this turning out all right, do you?
No.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 148
SCENE 110. INT. BUCHMAN OUTHOUSE. MORNING.
Veronica, I can’t let you do this!
What?
He’s right, Mum. Electrifying the loch. It’s murder. It’s wrong.
The Wirrn murdered your father. They murdered Sheer!
(SHOCKED) Sheer?
Yes, well, if you won’t listen to reason, Veronica — I’1l just have to undo the cables myself. (EFFORT, PULLING CABLES)
You’11 never work out which is which, Doctor. Maybe they’1l try another bomb in a minute, maybe they’1ll send a team in a month. But the longer it takes, the more that loch will be melted.
We’re not going to survive a month.
I thought the transmat had killed you. Now that wretched transmat will kill every Wirrn in Loch Lomond. Any way you look at it, that’s justice.
Please. Tell us how to find the right cables.
If I do that, we have nothing. The Wirrn win.
If you do this, Mum, then we have nothing. You and me.
THE PRODIGAL WIRRN by William Gallagher (003-AB) Page 149
SCENE 111. INT. NERVA CITY COUNCIL BUILDING. NIGHT.
It can’t be over. Except it is.
There were children out there. Babies. This Doctor could find a way to stop it?
I’d bet my life.
Not a great thing to say, just at the moment.
Right, look, what have we got? What do we know? There’s you and me, we seem to be safe.
For the moment. I should watch the monitors, see if Wirrn head back.
Anything else we’ve got? There’s the transmat. Is there anywhere we could go?
Everything on the network got a beacon and may well have Wirrn. The only place not on the net — oh. Oh. Hang on.
